Home.title: Colonial Collections Datahub
Home.description: The Colonial Collections Datahub is a digital platform that brings together, enriches and provides insights into information on collections from colonial contexts. It includes heritage from Suriname, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, South Africa, Aruba, Cura√ßao, Sint Maarten and many other countries and areas. The datahub provides communities and researchers space to add perspectives on the included data. <link>See how this works</link>
Home.searchPlaceholder: Tip: start searching for a location, e.g. Suriname
Home.narrativeExplainTitle: Add your narratives to heritage and objects
Home.narrativeExplainText:
Your knowledge about the heritage on this platform is vital. With your narratives and perspectives, we can present the 'objects' in their context and point to biases in collection metadata.

When you create an account, you can add your narrative to these 'objects', make communities and create lists.
Home.communitiesDescription: Upon creating an account, every individual or group of people can start their own community on this platform. A community is able to create lists of objects, bringing together their heritage. Communities can also add narratives to the objects in these collections.
Home.communitiesLink: Below are some communities to inspire you. Would you like to see all the communities on the platform? <link>Please click here</link>.
Home.howThisWorksText: Here is a short explanation on how to use the following functionalities on this website: search for objects, add narratives and use communities.
Home.howThisWorksAlt: An animation about how this site works.

ObjectSearch.title: Search for heritage objects
ObjectSearch.description:
Start by typing a keyword to search.

After this initial text search, search facets will appear to refine your search results.

SignUp.whyText:
With an account, you have access to more functionality on this website. You can add your narratives to the objects, be part of a community, or create lists to organise objects.

The reason one needs to create an account is that we want to know who adds the data. This is one of the ways we prevent anonymous spamming.
SignUp.whatTitle: What can I do with an account?
SignUp.addText:
One of the most important functionalities is that users can add their narratives to the objects on this site. Users can share how the objects are being used or name them in their own language.

<important>Please note</important>: To add a narrative you need to create an account using Google, Facebook or LinkedIn.
SignUp.useText: Communities are groups of people that represent a specific culture or geographical area. Anyone with an account can become a member of a community. You can also create your own community.

ObjectDetails.addToListSignedOutText:
If you want to add an object to a list you need to <signInLink>login</signInLink> or <signUpLink>create an account</signUpLink>.

If you have an account you can join a <communityLink>community</communityLink> to create a list.

TraditionalKnowledgeLabels.title: Traditional Knowledge Labels
TraditionalKnowledgeLabels.description: The TK Labels support the inclusion of local protocols for access and use to cultural heritage that is digitally circulating outside community contexts. <link> Learn more about the Traditional Knowledge Labels </link>.
TraditionalKnowledgeLabels.attributionIncompleteDescription: Collections and items in our institution have incomplete, inaccurate, and/or missing attribution. We are using this notice to clearly identify this material so that it can be updated, or corrected by communities of origin. Our institution is committed to collaboration and partnerships to address this problem of incorrect or missing attribution.
TraditionalKnowledgeLabels.defaultLabel: This is a default notice if no other labels or notices are asigned.

Provenance.title: Provenance
Provenance.description: Provenance information shows the trail an object has made before it came at the current location. It can contain information about previous owners to technical processing information. This provenance data is often incomplete.
Provenance.qualifier: The provider qualified this information as <qualifier></qualifier>
Provenance.noData: No provenance events provided for this object.
Provenance.timelineDescription: In the timeline provenance events are plotted out by time. Click on an event to focus on that event.
Provenance.timelineEventsWithoutDates: {eventCount, plural, =1 {Provenance event {events} is not plotted on the timeline because there are no dates available.} other {# Provenance events {events} are not plotted on the timeline because there are no dates available.}}
Provenance.needAccountToAddProvenanceTitle: To add provenance to this object you need to have an account.

ProvenanceForm.typeDescription: Select one of the options that best suit the situation.

ProvenanceForm.locationDescription: What is the new location of the object. Start typing to select a location.
ProvenanceForm.startDateDescription: If you have an exact date you can fill it in here. If you are not sure about the date you can select a range of dates in which the event occur.
ProvenanceForm.endDateDescription: If the start date is an exact date, place the same date as the start date.
ProvenanceForm.citationDescription: Please provide information that supports your provenance event.
ProvenanceForm.inLanguageDescription: Select a language of the provenance event. Start typing to select a language.

ProvenanceForm.license: I agree that all added information in the application is published with a <link>CC-BY-4.0 license</link>
ProvenanceForm.qualifierDescription: If you are uncertain about this information select one of the two options. If you are certain, leave them unchecked.
ProvenanceForm.agreedToLicenseUnchecked: You need to agree to the license before you can add a provenance event
ProvenanceForm.invalidDateRange: Invalid date range, start date should be before end date
ProvenanceForm.successfullyAdded: Your provenance event has been added to the object. It could take a moment before it is visible.
ProvenanceForm.serverError: Something went wrong while creating the provenance event. Please try again later.

CommunitySelector.noCommunities: You are not yet a member of a community. If you want your contribution to be part of a community, you can create a community or join an existing community.

MotivationInput.description: Please explain the reason or context for the information provided in the field above. Include any relevant sources, historical events, or specific circumstances that justify this entry.

Filters.aboutFacetsText:
The data of these facet items are collected from multiple datasets. We are in the process of improving the quality of these facets items.

Please note that currently, for some facets the items for search filters are provided in Dutch, regardless of the selected interface language. We're working on adding translations soon.

Communities.title: Communities
Communities.pageDescription:
Heritage communities are groups of people representing a specific culture or geographical area, or that connect to certain heritage for intrinsic reasons. On this platform, a community can make lists of objects and records that are meaningful to them, and provide them with context and perspectives.

The option to make a community is a direct response to the wishes expressed in an international user workshop for this platform. Since the workshop also brought forward the wish to have multiple perspectives coexist on the platform, a community is not an all-encompassing claim to representation, but rather an inclusive collaborative effort.
Communities.yourCommunityText: Use the search bar and filters below to discover communities that resonate with you. Selecting a community will give you a closer look at its lists of objects, and give you the option to join and contribute. Would you like to make a community?
Communities.yourCommunityTextSignedOut: With an account you can join a community or create one yourself.

ProvenanceEventType.bequestDescription: Method of acquiring property by transference or bestowal following the death of a benefactor, by means of the last will or other method.
ProvenanceEventType.donationDescription: Method of acquiring funds or property through transference of ownership from one party to another as a free gift.
ProvenanceEventType.giftDescription: General term for the method of acquiring property through transference by one person or institution to another person or institution, voluntarily and without any payment required.
ProvenanceEventType.transferDescription: Method of acquiring property by legally conferring existing ownership to another person or institution; it does not necessarily involve benefactors.
ProvenanceEventType.purchaseDescription: Method of acquiring property by payment of funds.
ProvenanceEventType.originalOwnerDescription: In cataloging art and cultural heritage, refers to the first known owner of the work, when the method of acquisition is unknown or not applicable.
ProvenanceEventType.restitutionDescription: The action of restoring or giving back something to its rightful owner, or of making reparation for a loss previously inflicted; restoration of a thing lost, taken, or damaged.
ProvenanceEventType.inheritanceDescription: Hereditary succession to property, quality, or immaterial possession. When the inheritance is transferred by a legal document such as a will, regardless of familial relationship, use 'bequest.'
ProvenanceEventType.stolenDescription: The status or condition of property having been obtained by theft.
ProvenanceEventType.lootDescription: The status or condition of property having been damaged or carried off as booty in time of war or unrest.
ProvenanceEventType.confiscatedDescription: The status or condition of property having been taken or forfeited by a governmental or other entity in power or having authority.

SignedOutSlideOut.description: With this account you can unlock more functionality of this platform. Creating an account free of charge. <link>See what else you can do with an account</link>.
